images.copyright: Mahatma Gandhi statue at Malpe Beach, Udupi, Karnataka (© Rainer Krack/Alamy)
images.title: A figure of peace
images.caption: Gandhi Jayanti
images.desc: A day that reminds us how simplicity can move mountains—Gandhi Jayanti celebrates the power of truth and non-violence. Recognised as one of the three national holidays in India, it also carries global significance as the United Nations has observed it since 2007 as the International Day of Non-Violence.

og.title: Gandhi Jayanti
og.desc: A day that reminds us how simplicity can move mountains—Gandhi Jayanti celebrates the power of truth and non-violence. Recognised as one of…

images.copyright: Goddess Durga idol at a puja pandal in Kolkata, West Bengal (© Arnav Pratap Singh/Getty Images)
images.title: Gracefully divine
images.caption: Maha Navami
images.desc: Maha Navami, the ninth day of Sharad Navratri, is an observance grounded in devotion, myth and tradition. It recalls the final day of Goddess Durga's battle with Mahishasura, the buffalo demon, before her ultimate victory on Vijaya Dashami. The day is seen as the culmination of Navratri devotion, symbolising the victory of righteousness over evil and preparing devotees to begin anew.

og.title: Maha Navami
og.desc: Maha Navami, the ninth day of Sharad Navratri, is an observance grounded in devotion, myth and tradition. It recalls the final day of…

images.copyright: Koala in a eucalyptus tree, Great Otway National Park, Australia (© Jamie Lamb - elusive-images.co.uk/Getty Images)
images.title: Clinging to what matters
images.caption: Koala in the Great Otway National Park, Australia
images.desc: Amid the lush eucalyptus canopy of Great Otway National Park, koalas reign as sleepy sentinels of Australia's wild soul. Often misnamed 'koala bears,' these marsupials are actually closer to wombats and tend to be instantly recognisable by their stout, tailless bodies, fluffy ears and velvety black noses.

og.title: Koala in the Great Otway National Park, Australia
og.desc: Amid the lush eucalyptus canopy of Great Otway National Park, koalas reign as sleepy sentinels of Australia's wild soul. Often misnamed…

images.copyright: Rainbow houses in the town of Houten, Netherlands (© George Pachantouris/Getty Images)
images.title: Rainbow rides and quiet vibes
images.caption: Rainbow houses, Houten, Netherlands
images.desc: You won't find souvenir shops or tourist maps pointing the way—but follow the edge of Lake Rietplas in Houten, and you'll stumble upon one of the Netherlands' most unexpectedly photogenic sights. While many flock to Amsterdam's canals or Rotterdam's cube houses, this quiet commuter town offers its own architectural twist. Lined up like a mirage, the Rainbow Houses shimmer in bold, painterly hues—a residential block turned an understated cultural landmark.

og.title: Rainbow houses, Houten, Netherlands
og.desc: You won't find souvenir shops or tourist maps pointing the way—but follow the edge of Lake Rietplas in Houten, and you'll stumble upon one…

images.copyright: Town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy (© zpagistock/Getty Images)
images.title: A taste of Pienza
images.caption: Town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy
images.desc: Some towns evolve slowly over centuries. Pienza? It received a full rebrand in the 1400s from a pope who wanted to prove a point—and maybe show off a little. This tiny Italian town is perched above the Val d'Orcia, surrounded by rolling hills that look exactly like you think Tuscany should: cypress trees, winding dirt roads, the occasional sheep. It's peaceful. And then you step inside the town walls, and it gets clever.

og.title: Town of Pienza in Tuscany, Italy
og.desc: Some towns evolve slowly over centuries. Pienza? It received a full rebrand in the 1400s from a pope who wanted to prove a point—and maybe…

images.copyright: Tank Lakes, Alpine Lakes Wilderness, Washington, United States (© Austin Trigg/TANDEM Stills + Motion)
images.title: Weeding and wishing
images.caption: Tank Lakes, Alpine Lakes Wilderness, Washington, United States
images.desc: Tucked away in the Central Cascades, the Alpine Lakes Wilderness, in Washington, United States, is shaped by glaciers and crowned with drama. Spanning over 1,600 square kilometres, it is the largest wilderness near Puget Sound and home to more than 700 lakes. Here, Tank Lakes shimmer like jewels against rugged peaks, many dusted year-round with snowfields. Trails weave through dripping Douglas fir and cedar forests where salal and berries thrive before opening into wildflower meadows and finally giving way to the dry forests of ponderosa pine.

og.title: Tank Lakes, Alpine Lakes Wilderness, Washington, United States
og.desc: Tucked away in the Central Cascades, the Alpine Lakes Wilderness, in Washington, United States, is shaped by glaciers and crowned with drama…

images.copyright: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States (© Donald M. Jones/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The fast and the furriest
images.caption: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States
images.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and turbo-charged feet, this tiny rodent proves that being 'least' is no reason to squirrel away your potential. Weighing less than a deck of cards and measuring under 30 centimetres from nose to tail, this species is North America's smallest chipmunk.

og.title: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States
og.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and…

images.title: Carved stones of courage
images.caption: Chittorgarh Fort, Rajasthan
images.desc: High on a hill of 180 metres in Rajasthan, Chittorgarh Fort spans approximately 3 kilometres. It stands as a proud witness to the valour of the Rajputs. Their name comes from the Sanskrit 'rajaputra,' meaning 'son of a king,' and they are celebrated for their noble lineage and martial traditions across northern India. The fort's stone walls have witnessed centuries of courage, pride and romance, remembered in the songs of Rajasthan's bards. Local lore credits Bhim of the Pandavas, the five warrior princes of the Mahabharata, with laying its first foundations.
